references:
Prior studies have demonstrated that neural networks are vulnerable to evasion attacks by adversarial examplesÂ (Goodfellow, Shlens, and Szegedy 2014) during inference time. The goal of inference-time adversarial attackÂ (Li etÂ al. 2021a; Chen etÂ al. 2022c; Zhang etÂ al. 2022b; Chen etÂ al. 2022b) is to
damage the global model by adding a carefully generated imperceptible perturbation on the test examples.
As shown in TableÂ 1, federated models are as fragile to adversarial examples as centrally trained models (i.e.â€‰ zero accuracy under PGD-40 attackÂ (Madry etÂ al. 2017)). Hence, it is also important to consider how to defend against adversarial attacks in federated learning.

In this work, we conduct a systematic study on several state-of-the-art FL algorithms including FedAvgÂ (McMahan etÂ al. 2017), FedProxÂ (Li etÂ al. 2018), FedNovaÂ (Wang etÂ al. 2020) and ScaffoldÂ (Karimireddy etÂ al. 2020), and explore their combinations with AT methods to defend against adversarial attacks. We report detailed results in TableÂ 2, here robustness is averaged over four popular attacks (FGSMÂ (Kurakin, Goodfellow, and Bengio 2017), MIMÂ (Dong etÂ al. 2018), PGDÂ (Madry etÂ al. 2017), and CWÂ (Carlini and Wagner 2017)). Besides, we implement some prevailing adversarial training methods including PGD_ATÂ (Madry etÂ al. 2017)
, TRADESÂ (Zhang etÂ al. 2019), ALPÂ (Kannan, Kurakin, and Goodfellow 2018), MMAÂ (Ding etÂ al. 2020) and AVMixupÂ (Lee, Lee, and Yoon 2020). We observe that there is no federated adversarial learning algorithm that can outperform all the others in all cases. Moreover, the clean accuracy drops heavily under non-IID distribution.
As such, we are motivated to develop a more effective method. Due to the similar performance of these FL methods observed from TableÂ 2, we design our method based on FedAvg â€“ a representative algorithm in FL.

To show the differences between DBFAT and
above mentioned defense methods, we report the training curves on non-IID CIFAR10 dataset in the right sub-figure of Fig.Â 6.
Fig.Â 6 confirms that our DBFAT achieves the highest clean accuracy.
We speculate that this benefit is due to the regularization term and re-weighting strategy introduced in Equation 6. It is worth mentioning that in the training curves, the model trained with PGD_AT performs very poorly. It indicates that standard AT may not be a suitable choice for adversarial robustness in FL, as it only uses cross-entropy loss with adversarial examples, but ignores the negative impact on clean accuracy.
We further report the results on various datasets under both IID and non-IID settings in Table 4, which indicates that DBFAT significantly outperforms other methods in terms of both accuracy and robustness.

In TableÂ 5, we show the accuracy and robustness of each method on large datasets (e.g., CIFAR100, Tiny-ImageNet, and ImageNet-12). All results are tested under PGD-20 attackÂ (Madry etÂ al. 2017), AutoAttackÂ (Croce and Hein 2020), and Square attackÂ (Andriushchenko etÂ al. 2020) in non-IID settings. From the results reported in TableÂ 5, we can find that our method still outperforms other baselines in terms of both clean accuracy and robustness. Note that our method can achieve the highest accuracy and robustness of 61.38% and 22.08% under AutoAttack, respectively. It thus proves that our method can also be used to improve the accuracy and robustness of the model on large datasets.
We think that the higher clean accuracy is a result of the regularization term introduced in EquationÂ 6, while maintaining a high robustness.

As part of our ablation study, we first investigate the contributions of different modules introduced in DBFAT. As shown in TableÂ 6, turning off both the re-weighting strategy and regularization term will lead to poor performance, which demonstrates the
importance of both modules. Moreover, cut-offing the re-weighting strategy can lead to a more severe degradation.
We conjecture this is a reasonable phenomenon. As mentioned in Fig.Â 1, non-IID data can cause a serious accuracy reduction. Our re-weighting strategy can alleviate the bias by taking the limited data on each client into account.

The regularization parameter Î²ğ›½\beta is an important hyperparameter in our proposed method. We show how the regularization parameter affects the performance of our robust classifiers by numerical experiments on two datasets, MNIST and FMNIST. In Equation 6, Î²ğ›½\beta controls the accuracy obtained from the global model, which contains information from distributed clients. Since directly training on adversarial examples could hurt the clean accuracy, here we explore the effects of Î²ğ›½\beta on both accuracy and robustness.
As shown in Table 7, we report the clean accuracy and robustness by varying the value of Î²ğ›½\beta.
We empirically choose the best Î²ğ›½\beta for different datasets. For example, for MNIST, Î²=1.5ğ›½1.5\beta=1.5 can achieve better accuracy and robustness. For FMNIST, we let Î²=2ğ›½2\beta=2 for a proper trade-off in accuracy and robustness.
